**The Song of Returning Elixir from the Western Furnace of Mount Penglai**

**Title:** *The Song of Returning Elixir from the Western Furnace of Mount Penglai*
**Original Author:** Attributed to Huang Xuanzhong of the Han, though official titles, place names, and literary style suggest a Tang-era forgery. Originally one scroll, later divided into two.
**Source:** *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Compendia of the Divine Empyrean Section*, *Miscellaneous Arts Category*.

---

### *The Song of Returning Elixir from the Western Furnace of Mount Penglai, Scroll One*
**Composed by Huang Xuanzhong, Han Examiner of the Court of Judicature and Revision, Grand Master for Glorious Happiness with Gold and Purple Insignia**

Your servant has heard that the wren in the trees does not seek more than a single branch for its nest, and the field mouse drinks from the river only to fill its belly. Yet Your Majesty’s fame surpasses that of Donghu, and your governance harmonizes the southern winds, bringing peace to the myriad people—none fail to find repose. Why then do you prize the glory of the imperial chariot yet slight the Dao of immortality?

Your servant humbly submits: In the Yuanfeng era, by imperial decree, I journeyed to Mount Penglai to seek the wondrous arts. I endured the perils of the sea, traversed the hidden yang, and risked death in pursuit of the supreme Dao. By the distant grace of Your Majesty’s favor, moved by this humble servant’s devotion, I encountered a great immortal who bestowed upon me the sacred elixir. With utmost sincerity, I presented it to the throne. How could Your Majesty heed the words of flattering ministers, mistaking it for heresy and deceit, and command your servant to consume it himself? Soon after, I took leave of the imperial court, overcome with sorrow and longing. Before I could fully explore the palaces, a decade passed in fleeting moments, and I feared that leisurely deliberation would forever bar my return.

Later, I learned that Your Majesty had ordered Dongfang Shuo to summon the Queen Mother of the West and erect a dew-receiving basin—clear proof of Your Majesty’s deep regret. Your servant has heard that to serve one’s lord with loyalty and stand by one’s friends with righteousness is the way of the minister. Disloyalty to the sovereign invites punishment from all officials; betrayal of friends brings abandonment by all companions. At the Western Furnace of the Shaowei Courtyard in the Ziyang Palace, I personally received the wondrous Dao of the returning elixir and secretly recorded its formula. I implore Your Majesty to heed the admonitions of loyal ministers and verify this method. Do not repeat the errors of past years by yielding to the words of vulgar flatterers.

The elixir shall be compounded by Left Reminder Chen Fangjing, with Right Aide Zhou Zhenyuan overseeing the firing. My son, Zhicheng, will tend the furnace and perform the offerings, ensuring the refinement is precise and subtle. With earnest devotion, may the purple jade briefly appear, and may Your Majesty’s bones become golden for eternity.

Why cling to the grandeur of the Hanlin Palace, which is but the essence of the mortal realm? The Northern Gate and Western Hall are far from vast; the Nine Divisions of the Imperial Sacrifices cannot compare to true harmony; the powdered and rouged chambers are but ugly vessels. How much more sublime is the unparalleled wonder of Mount Penglai, famed as the immortal mountain! Here stand the palaces of the sun and moon, cloud chambers and golden pavilions. Halls are adorned with gold and jade, towers gleam with coral, magpies encircle sacred mushrooms, and simurghs soar among jade trees. Heavenly boys and jade maidens stir the cauldrons with song, while rare birds and famed fowl arrive without cease. Beyond the crystal curtains, the mysterious wind rustles; within the jasper doors, fine rain drizzles. A single sip of jade nectar grants a thousand years; a moment’s taste of the great elixir ensures ten thousand ages. Soon you will witness the mulberry fields turn to sea, and the sea revert to mulberry fields. Some ascend to attend the Heavenly Elder, others pass through the Cloud Gate, descending to Yingzhou to seek rare treasures. The yellow-roofed halls of the mortal world are not worthy of reverence; even the embroidered robes of high ministers cannot compare in nobility.

Why does Your Majesty not personally visit these wondrous realms, instead suffering the bonds of the mundane? Soon you will see your crown entombed in the stone hall, your body buried in the earth, leaving your descendants to kneel in vain, pouring libations at your cold mausoleum. In the span of a morning and evening, this fate will be upon you. Even a hundred years as Son of Heaven cannot equal a single day as an immortal.

I beseech Your Majesty’s sagacious judgment: do not seek your own demise.

Respectfully dispatched, the Elixir-Bearing Youth of Nanyang, to present this memorial for Your Majesty’s consideration.

**Huang Xuanzhong, Right Senior Minister of the Purple Tenuity of Mount Penglai’s Nanyang, prostrates and respectfully submits.**

All who uphold this sacred Dao must seek it without deviation, through purity, fasting, and tranquil contemplation. The furnace must be established and the stove arranged; one must not act contrary to the divine methods. Every movement and mechanism must align with the Dao of Heaven. The mineral and herbal ingredients must be of the finest quality, without error.

All herbs are tribute from the provinces, save three varieties native to this mountain. Six common mortal ingredients may be substituted, as listed below.

**One Song of the Yellow Tooth Stone** (for crafting the Yellow Tooth elixir, five-character verse)
**One Hundred Seventy-Two Herbal Songs** (describing the forms, names, harvesting seasons, and properties of 172 herbs, including their times of vitality and decay)
**Total: 168 songs**

### **Crafting the Yellow Tooth, First Method**
**Song:**
Layer *ren* [water phase] in repeated folds,
Lead and yellow powder in successive weights.
The white and yellow of *you-niu* [rooster-metal] in three hues,
Blend with the brine of the eastern tail.
Place *bing-ding* [fire phase] atop,
Together enter the red flames.

Follow the song’s instructions, layering repeatedly until *ren* is exhausted. The process should align with the Summer Solstice. Grind with ice stone for best results. Use the eastern tail [direction], but avoid days of *jia-wu-geng* [wood, earth, metal] and fixed [inauspicious] dates.

### **Second Herb: Dewy Countenance Grass**
**Common Name:** Earth Record
**Textual Name:** Stone Record
Stem and flowers are red, nature toxic. Dislikes rough texture; grows on cliffs. Native to Henan. Vital in *jia-yi* [wood phase], perishes in *wu-ji* [earth phase]. Harvest on *jia-yin* day; leaves are round. Gather twenty days after the Spring Equinox. Primarily treats malignant sores. Aligns with the Spring Equinox.

**Song:**
This herb is found among men,
Henan yields the rarest kind.
Pluck and blend with mercury,
Overnight it answers heaven’s truth.

---

### **Third Herb: Frosty Countenance Grass**
**Common Name:** Heaven’s Edge
**Textual Name:** White Microbe
Nature as above. Native to the southern roads of Ke. Vital in *jia-ren* [wood-water], perishes in *wu-gui* [earth-water]. Vines bear three flowers. Aligns with the Summer Solstice. Harvest after the Beginning of Spring.

**Song:**
From distant trees, climb the cliffs,
Three flowers face the peaks.
Pluck and bury in *yi* [wood] earth,
Follow the eastern tail’s method, then enter *gui-ren* [water phase].

---

### **Fourth Herb: Twin Husband Grass**
**Common Name:** Hibiscus Vine
**Textual Name:** Purple Jade
Nature as above. Treats consumptive illness. Native to Annan Prefecture.

**Fourth Herb: Twin Husband Grass (continued)**
Native to *bing-ding* [fire phase], perishes in *jia-ji* [wood-earth]. Leaves purple-green, varying in size. Aligns with the Lesser Heat solar term. Harvest after the Beginning of Summer.

**Song:**
Vines climb toward heaven’s waters,
By the pond, flowers bloom near stone.
Wait for the *bing-ding* hour of night,
The Weaver Girl’s form must be firm.

**Fifth Herb: Stone Heaven**
**Common Name:** Fishing Line Grass
**Textual Name:** Martial Grass
Mildly toxic. Native to the northern frontier. Manifests as metal, with a long, verdant hue. Native to *jia-ren* [wood-water], perishes in *ding-mao* [fire-rabbit]. Treats mercury poisoning and intestinal wind.

**Song:**
Across the land, sharp leaves unfurl,
Seek the mountains for their green glow.
Use fermented mash at Summer Solstice,
Harvest when the wild geese return.

**Sixth Herb: Stone Mysterious**
**Common Name:** Vine of Bitterness
**Textual Name:** Recorded Branch
Warm in nature. Hardens mercury. Green in color. Native to *wu-ji* [earth], perishes in *ding-ren* [fire-water]. Treats abdominal paralysis. Aligns with the Lesser Heat solar term. Harvest after the Beginning of Autumn.

**Song:**
Black vines bear green leaves,
Born again in wild marshes.
Calmly place upon *bing* [fire],
Only then will mighty strength arise.

**Seventh Herb: Ten-Thousand-Year Spring**
**Common Name:** Water Indigo
**Textual Name:** Earth Mirror
Cool in nature. Native to the Jiangnan region. Resembles indigo—young leaves blue-green, aging to red. Native to *wu-ding* [earth-fire], perishes in *jia-ji* [wood-earth].

**Eighth Herb: Thousand-Autumn Brocade**
**Common Name:** Earth Curtain
**Textual Name:** Green Loft
Treats infantile malnutrition. Aligns with the Greater Cold solar term. Harvest ten days after the Spring Equinox.

**Song:**
Green in hue, pointed and red—like indigo in form,
Dwelling on lofty peaks or deep in pools.
First paired with the Returned Elixir as its abode,
Cool in nature yet sweet in taste.

**Ninth Herb: Everlasting Spring**
**Common Name:** Shade Ganoderma
**Textual Name:** Green Heart
Warm in nature. Native to Jiannan. Native to *jia-yi* [wood], perishes in *wu-ji* [earth]. Leaves large as a hand’s palm, wrinkled. Treats severe wind disorders. Aligns with the Greater Heat solar term. Harvest after the Beginning of Summer.

**Song:**
Wrinkled leaves unfurl by distant mountain springs,
Large and pointed green, small and round.
Only in Jiannan does it grow finest—
The Perfected call it the Herb of the Cinnabar Field.

**Tenth Herb: Cold Cicada Leaf**
**Common Name:** Beauty Grass
**Textual Name:** Warm Grass
Native to Bazhou and Pengzhou. Resembles a cicada’s wing—shoots blue-green or red, varying. Native to *wu-ding* [earth-fire], withers in *jia-xu* [wood-earth]. Treats red and white vaginal discharge. Aligns with the Rain Water solar term. Harvest after the Beginning of Autumn.

**Song:**
Leaves like cicada wings, stems like cords,
Ever by the pool’s edge, mirrored in clear water.
When the time is right, gather three or five—
Eight *zhu* of golden powder, three *sheng* of sap.

**Eleventh Herb: Thousand Spirits**
*(Text continues)*

**Twelfth Herb: Red Horse State**
**Common Name:** Earth Receptacle
**Textual Name:** Purple Canopy
Nature: Toxic
Native to Beiji. Stems and leaves purple. Grows in *jia-ren* [wood-water], withers in *ding-ji* [fire-earth]. Treats retching and hiccups. Aligns with the Spring Equinox solar term. Harvest after the Spring Equinox.

**Song:**
Branches red, leaves purple cling to cliffs,
This herb the Perfected secretly array.
Just when the furnace’s dragon unfurls,
Then you’ll know my jade-like numinous power.

**Thirteenth Herb: Ten Thousand Sunlit Blossoms**
**Common Name:** Hu Wave Water Chestnut
**Textual Name:** Beauty Vegetable
Nature: Benign
Native to Hebei. Leaves green, flowers purple. Grows in *jia-ji* [wood-earth], withers in *ding-ren* [fire-water]. Treats malignant sores. Aligns with the Summer Solstice solar term. Harvest after the White Dew.

**Song:**
Cluster on cluster, leaves thrust forth from marshland’s birth,
Summer blooms near spring’s verdant verge.
Add to the red kiln and simmer within—
In ten days’ decoction, this herb most potent proves.

**Song:**
Petals of the water chestnut, snipped as if by scissors’ blade,
Each year the Perfected Ones themselves bestow this aid.
Should you seek its purple chambers free of purple hue,
Pluck and boil it with the womb-stone’s embryo true.

**Fourteenth Herb: Cold Spring Mirror**
**Common Name:** Large-Leaf Duckweed
**Textual Name:** Pool’s Countenance
Nature: Cool
Native to Yunnan. Leaves round, floating upon the water. Grows in *bing-ding* [fire-fire], withers in *jia-yi* [wood-wood]. Treats malignant sores. Aligns with the Grain Full solar term. Harvest after the Summer Begins.

**Song:**
Floating life on ponds—leaves verdant, bright,
In sapphire-toothed elixirs, most numinous in might.
Henceforth with mercury beneath the sun’s gaze,
Even gold shall strive in vain for fame’s praise.

**Fifteenth Herb: Cavern Stalks**
**Common Name:** Zhou Zhi
**Textual Name:** Lu’s Countenance
Nature: Hot
Native to Luozhou. Leaves green, branches white and sour. Grows in *jia-ding* [wood-fire], withers in *wu-ji* [earth-earth]. Treats poisonous winds. Aligns with the Grain Full solar term. Harvest after the Summer Begins.

**Song:**
Leaves green, stems tart, sprouting from the mound,
Thorned blooms like upturned bowls abound.
If the Returned Cinnabar bypasses the pool’s embrace,
How shall immortals vie for a ten-thousand-year grace?

**Sixteenth Herb: Duke Without Seizure**
**Common Name:** Stone Vine
**Textual Name:** Moistening Spring
Native to the Southern Mountains of Chang’an. Leaves like beans, vines trailing purple. Grows in *ding-ji* [fire-earth], wilts in *wu-ren* [earth-water]. Treats malignant sores. Aligns with the Great Cold solar term. Harvest after the White Dew.

**Song:**
Cluster on cluster, purple shadows rise from Chang’an’s plain,
Born at spring’s first breath, its hue defies the cold’s domain.
When plucking at the crumbling cliffs, beware the torrents’ reign,
And guard against the myriad spirits’ watchful gaze and feign.

**Seventeenth Herb: Heaven’s Mirror Cold**
**Common Name:** Stone Fan
**Textual Name:** Green-Backed
Native to the Henan Circuit. Each stem bears but a single leaf.

**Seventeenth Herb: Heaven’s Mirror Cold**
**Common Name:** Stone Fan
**Textual Name:** Green-Backed
Native to the Henan Circuit. Each stem bears but a single leaf. Grows in *wu-ren* [earth-water], wilts in *jia-ji* [wood-earth]. Treats cold. Aligns with the Beginning of Summer solar term. Harvest after the original text’s omission.

**Song:**
Leaves like woven fans cling to cliffs’ sheer face,
Each tree bears but one stem in its embrace.
From graves and dead springs, all effect is vain,
Sever man from dog—then its power shall reign.

**Eighteenth Herb: Free-Flowing Trails**
**Common Name:** Purple Cowrie Vine
**Textual Name:** Cliff Mugwort
Cold in nature. Native to Sanyuan County. Leaves pointed. Aligns with the White Dew solar term. Harvest after the Winter Solstice.

**Song:**
Branches trail, vines unfurl like golden orchids bright,
Only true immortals’ hands may pluck its sacred light.
To ascend the Purple Tenuity’s celestial gate,
How wondrous its radiance upon the Daoist altar’s state.

**Nineteenth Herb: Corpse-Release Red**
**Common Name:** Stone Quilt
**Textual Name:** Earth Veins
Warm in nature. Native to Yangzhou. Resembles duckweed, stems slender. Grows in *yi-gui* [wood-water], wilts in *you-xu* [metal-dog]. Treats all visceral counterflow and malignities. Aligns with the Lesser Cold solar term. Harvest after the Beginning of Summer.

**Song:**
Green cliffs near stone, its form like shears refined,
Purple Tower and Penglai share its name enshrined.
Alone with cinnabar and mercury it’s wrought,
Beneath the flame, copper’s ring is forever naught.

**Twentieth Herb: Immortal’s Node Ganoderma**
**Common Name:** Stone Contest
**Textual Name:** Nine Accumulations
Cool in nature. Native to Henan. Shape pointed and fine, nodes clustered. Grows in *wu-ding* [earth-fire], wilts in *yi-gui* [wood-water]. Treats heat oppression and leg qi. Aligns with the Autumn Equinox. Harvest after the Beginning of Winter.

**Song:**

**Song:**
In heaven’s realm it wholly lacks, yet earthly bounds possess its grace,
Unrecognized by mortal kind, it withers in its native place.
This day unfolds its golden lore,
That monarchs hence may know its name evermore.

**Twenty-First Herb: Gilded Terrace Ganoderma**
**Common Name:** Horse Purslane
**Textual Name:** Green Essence
Cold in nature. Native to Heyang Prefecture. Leaves sharp and round, slightly fermented. Grows in *jia-ding* [wood-fire], wilts in *ren-ji* [water-earth]. Treats sores and malign boils. Aligns with the Cold Dew solar term. Harvest after the Beginning of Winter.

**Song:**
When the Net-Spinner’s Bride had yet to ascend,
She plucked this Gilded Terrace by the hundred.
Through three cycles of sixty years she passed,
Then soared aloft on clouds of jubilation.

**Twenty-Second Herb: Light Gold Essence**
**Common Name:** Stone Branch
**Textual Name:** Supreme Distance
Native to Leyang. Treats deafness.

**Song:**
Cold leaves cluster thick along the winding way,
A treasure in the heavens, rare on mortal clay.
Plucked and boiled in a pot with White Nightshade,
Then shall its wondrous power be displayed.

**Twenty-Third Herb: Celestial Ganoderma**
**Common Name:** Capital’s Elixir
**Textual Name:** Heaven’s Void
Native to Luozhou. Treats windstroke.

**Song:**
Crimson pearls its seeds, the tree so green,
Purple Terrace’s Immortal gives it name anew.
Yet with Cinnabar Yang it turns to white,
Only then does Green Essence dare the Dark Abyss pursue.

**Twenty-Fourth Herb: Jade Pool**
**Common Name:** Jade Pool Willow
**Textual Name:** Radiant Ganoderma
Native to Jiangzhou. Stem pale green, leaves slender and fine. Treats toothache, wind-sores, and gan.

**Song:**
In mountain courts no Jade Willow grew,
Yet mortals err in calling it so.
When gathering, take but little—heed this rule,
Lest the immortal’s pouch or pharmacy overflow.

**Twenty-Fifth Herb: Ten-Thousand Perfections Lotus**
**Common Name:** Mountain Sweet Chrysanthemum
**Textual Name:** Water’s Husband
Resembles sweet chrysanthemum. Treats ghostly qi.

**Song:**

**Song:**
Vermilion peaks, their beauty shuns the lofty slope,
Yet where Yang’s favor lingers, here it thrives in droves.
Gathered, it must be used at once—heed well this law,
Lest Heaven’s messenger ferry it across the rivers’ flow.

**Twenty-Seventh Herb: Celestial Mystery**
**Common Name:** Stone Sweet
**Textual Name:** Earth’s Sweet
Native to Zhongwanzhou. Leaves green, growing upon stone. Treats regurgitation.

**Song:**
Within the stone lies fire, fire conceals the Yin,
Yang’s qi latent rises—efficacy like gold.
When gathering by day, beware the barking hound,
For if the dog should bark, its use will not take hold.

**Twenty-Eighth Herb: Stone Heavenly Zither**
**Common Name:** Stone Permitted
**Textual Name:** Returning Ganoderma
Leaves of three colors. Treats all wind disorders.

**Song:**
In Jingzhou’s imperial prefecture, all men ail,
Their sickness borne of earth’s surging qi.
Add and release the Returning Elixir, simmered overnight,
From hence a century free of wind’s decree.

**Twenty-Ninth Herb: Furry Camphor**
**Common Name:** Great Perfection
**Textual Name:** Forest Ganoderma
Cold in nature. Native to Henan Circuit. Resembles purple chrysanthemum. Treats wind-jaundice.

**Song:**
This uncarved block, when carved, blooms with flowered nodes,
Within its downy fur, seeds branch and spread.
Pity this thing—though found among men,
Who among men knows its name, filled with dread?

The preceding eight herbs: born in *jia-ren*, die in *yi-gui*, aligned with the Winter Solstice. Gather after the Beginning of Spring.

**Thirtieth Herb: Ten-Thousand-Year Perfection**
**Common Name:** Five-Spirit Ganoderma
**Textual Name:** None recorded.

**Thirty-First Herb: Purple Leaf**
**Common Name:** None recorded.
**Textual Name:** None recorded.
Cold in nature. Treats demonic qi and heartway aberrations.

**Song:**
Swaying brocade vines rise from Chang’an,
Facing snow, they bloom beyond the upper balustrade.
No need for spring’s glory—hidden, they bear fruit in secret,
The Heavenly Maidens of Great Luo feast upon them always.

**Thirty-Second Herb: Gold-Grain Cold**
**Common Name:** Wrinkled Face
**Textual Name:** Martial Ganoderma
Warm in nature. Native to Hengzhou. Leaves large as a hand’s span, wrinkled. Treats wind-lichen.

**Song:**
Leaf upon leaf spreads across the sand, growing everywhere,
Immortal beings plant them around their immortal courts.
Know only the days of *wu-ji*, *geng-xin*—
Gather then, how could one fail to attain numinous communion?

**Thirty-Third Herb: Barbarian Chrysanthemum**
**Common Name:** Willow Pond
**Textual Name:** Heart-Barrier Grass
Warm in nature. Leaves like willow, trailing vines. Treats women’s blood and qi.

**Song:**
Green gold scatters emerald, trailing golden tendrils,
Verdant leaves drift lonely, circling the azure heavens.
Gather with the vines in the third month of spring—
Pity the mercury burning within the fire.

The preceding three herbs: born in *wu-ji-ding*, die in *jia-yi*. Aligned with the Great Cold, gather after the Beginning of Winter.

**Thirty-Fourth Herb: Heaven-Pointed Gold**

**Thirty-Fifth Herb: Barbarian Yam Vine**
**Common Name:** Hu Shu Vine
**Textual Name:** Beauty’s Grace
Hot in nature, toxic. Treats insect and snake poisons. Found in Meiyuan County, resembling *shu yu* (yam).

**Song:**
Thick leaves of blue-green gold, thriving by the stream—
Pity the immortal herb that mortals fail to see.
If you would ascend to heaven on high,
Take only this as your cloud-ladder.

**Thirty-Sixth Herb: Jade Unfolds Spring**
**Common Name:** Mountain Dendrobium
**Textual Name:** River Spring
Warm in nature. Native to Khotan. Three leaves, resembling elm.

**Song:**
Each tree bears three leaves, their distant glow like elm,
As winter divides and spring’s season draws near.
The immortal plucks it, pacing the void.

**Thirty-Seventh Herb: Thorny Bean Vine**
**Common Name:** True Zhi
**Textual Name:** [None]
Warm in nature. Found in Jiannan. Three leaves, resembling beans. Treats blood-wind.

**Song:**
Each leaf bears immortal intent, embracing emptiness to gain the great tone.
Thirty days within the golden casket—
No need to cast it into the depths.

**Thirty-Eighth Herb: Night-Closed Tree**
**Common Name:** Returning Heart
**Textual Name:** Pine South
Native to Shangzhou. Grows as a tree with small leaves that close at night. Treats heart-madness.

**Song:**
Lovely tree with tender leaves, branches open at dawn, close at dusk.
Pity the tree of heaven—
Fit to bear mortals in flight.

**Thirty-Ninth Herb: Purple Square Heaven**
**Common Name:** Willow-Leaf Mustard
**Textual Name:** [None]
Hot in nature. Found in Qingzhou. Leaves like willow, several inches long, exuding sap. Treats all wind-evil.

**Song:**
Small leaves bloom beside the mountain, planted by the immortal’s own hand.
From this, discern the true herb—
Before your eyes, journey to Mount Tiantai.

**Fortieth Herb: King [Illegible]**
**Common Name:** Green Wind
**Textual Name:** [None]
Toxic. A cluster of several leaves. Found in Yangmeimao. Treats meridians and hemorrhoids.

**Song:**
Earth parts to reveal jade leaves, branches rising alone to claim the azure sky.
Though many stone medicines may subdue,
None match the yin spirit in its power.

**Forty-First Herb: Red Lotus**
**Common Name:** Stone Sword
**Textual Name:** [None]
Hot in nature. Found in Ganzhou. A cluster of several blades. Treats all wind.

**Song:**
Brocade stone moss grows where clouds and rain gather,
The red lotus unfurls like a sword’s edge.
No decoction boils jade so well as this—
Thus did the immortal bestow its name.

**Forty-Second Herb: Barbarian Xin Vine**
**Common Name:** Three-Leaf Grass
**Textual Name:** Profound Truth
Toxic. Found in Jiangzhou. Leaves with three points. Treats insect poison.

**Song:**
Branches and twigs, leaves sharp as blades,
Near summer, as autumn nears, the vine begins to climb.
Only after the third turning of the third month
Is the formula complete—then fire it in the flame.

**Forty-Third Herb: Purple Immortal Zhi**
**Common Name:** Heavenly Pool
**Textual Name:** [None]
Hot in nature. Leaves resembling loquat.

**Forty-First Herb: Purple Immortal Zhi**
**Treats:** Heart pain.

**Song:**
The swaying immortal fruit grows by mountain streams,
Fit to serve as a ladder to Penglai’s square acre.
Often among men, yet men know it not—
Thus did Peach Source’s path become lost to them.

**Forty-Second Herb: Stone Bean Vine**
**Common Name:** Stay-with-Me
**Textual Name:** Single Chapter
Cold and toxic in nature. Leaves pointed, with trailing vines and stems of purple-green.
**Treats:** Insect poison.

**Song:**
Black jade for stems, gold for its fragrance,
It stretches its vines across rocky slopes.
The maiden of southern Qin once used it—
To refine mercury smokeless in the crucible’s flame.

**Forty-Third Herb: Mountain Stone Vine**
**Common Name:** True Fish
**Textual Name:** [None]
Warm in nature. Found in Wenzhou. Leaves with three points, resembling large beans.
**Treats:** Inverted sores.

**Song:**
Jade spread on golden vessels, inscribed among men,
Its sprouts in Peng Palace, its fruit in the fields.
It must be that the five centers are like snow—
How could all other things compare to its dusky mist?

**Forty-Fourth Herb: Jade Millet Grass**
**Common Name:** Traveling Needle
**Textual Name:** [None]
Found in Henan. Cold in nature. Resembles *huan* vine, with seeds like broomcorn millet.
**Treats:** Wind-heat.

**Song:**
Gold and jade arrayed in pearl-like grains,
Heaven and earth each bear their distinct forms.
When it grows in heaven, it is purple-green;
When found among men, it is sparse and green.

**Forty-Fifth Herb: Layered Gold**
**Common Name:** Small Yam Medicine
**Textual Name:** [None]
Warm in nature. Found in Chen Jinzhou. Leaves resemble yam, with roots.
**Treats:** Water diseases.

**Song:**
Bury its root in a golden casket, unfurl its lotus head,
The True Man of Creation left it behind long ago.
Remember well the five turnings when they unfold—
Boil it to water, and the five metals will soften.
*(Also called* Earth Su.)

**Forty-Sixth Herb: Stone Fern**
**Common Name:** Lost Darkness
**Textual Name:** Lingering Gold
Hot in nature. Found in Chu lands. Branches with numerous leaves.
**Treats:** Wind-cold.

**Song:**

**Forty-Seventh Herb: Jingyu**
**Common Name:** Jinmu Flower
**Textual Name:** [None]
Warm in nature. Found in Shannan Circuit. Vines with four ridges, pointed leaves.
**Treats:** Blood and qi disorders.

**Song:**
Clustered with pointed leaves and four-ridged stems,
Its light claims the vernal equinox, thriving wild across the fields.
Later generations studying the Dao all use this—
Know then that from this comes longevity.

**Forty-Eighth Herb: Layered Vine**
**Common Name:** Human Affection
**Textual Name:** Quji
Hot in nature. Found in Jiangnan Circuit. Small leaves grow first, then large leaves extend along the vine.
**Treats:** All sores.

**Song:**
The swelling True Qi ascends to heaven,
Just at the vernal equinox, it descends to the wild fields.
If met with green salt and blended together,
Know then that the living carriage emerges among men.

**Forty-Ninth Herb: Returning-Bone Herb**
**Common Name:** Rat’s Milkvetch
**Textual Name:** Single Mugwort
Hot in nature. Grows in Jianzhou. Stems like mugwort, with purple leaves.
**Breaks and treats:** Wind sores.

**Song:**
[...] buried where a thousand returns,
The wheel of life and death ascends the azure mountains.
If only you recognize this boiled in the pot,
After the fire, the golden body emerges into the world.

**Fiftieth Herb: Slightly Purple**
**Common Name:** Purple Cowrie
**Textual Name:** [None]
**Treats:** Paralysis and numbness.

**Song:**
Within the copper vase, cinnabar frost is spread,
Frost like mist-shrouded smoke, yet without light.
Suddenly, it melts further at the moment of solidity—
Pity the hue surpasses even jade.

**Fifty-First Herb: Cold-Stone Sunflower**
**Common Name:** Attached Mugwort
**Textual Name:** Inquiry Mushroom
Leaves round like mugwort. Hard in nature. Treats wind.

**Song:**
Mountains embrace their hues around the mountain court,
Countless immortals cultivate it in the capital.
Only when blended with cinnabar and yang powder—
Once boiled, the bronze’s ring is forever stilled.

**Fifty-Second Herb: Silk-Veined Vine**
**Common Name:** Snake Onion
**Textual Name:** Fitting One
Hot in nature. Grows in Qizhou. Veined like silk. Treats regurgitation.

**Song:**
Vines spread, stems rise along green streams,
Pity its strength rivals the mountains.
If you can add fish-water through the night,
Even bones buried for years may yet return.

**Fifty-Third Herb: Chicken-Gut Vine**
**Common Name:** Forest Watcher
**Textual Name:** [None]
Warm in nature. Grows in Baizhou. Leaves like chicken intestines. Treats all difficult births.

**Song:**
Vines extend, stems sprout across ten thousand li,
Branches gain color, claiming spring’s glory.
From this, cinnabar knows no blackness—
Within mercury, the Purple River’s name must appear.

**Fifty-Fourth Herb: Black-Gold Foot**
**Common Name:** Supreme Mushroom
**Textual Name:** Inauspicious
Hot in nature. Grows in Jiangling Prefecture. Stalks like black hairpins, leaves like ferns. Treats waist and leg ailments.

**Song:**
Golden crow feet scatter the cold mountains,
Immortal seekers strain their eyes in longing.
Once you grasp the Primordial’s wisdom,
Take care never to pass it to another.

**Fifty-Fifth Herb: Snake-Holding Chrysanthemum**
**Common Name:** Single Mushroom
**Textual Name:** [None]
Warm in nature. Grows in Taiyuan. Leaves like a snake’s bite, flowers like chrysanthemums. Treats throat obstruction.

**Song:**
The former herb bears flowers like green willows,
Golden vines spread along the brookside.
When harvesting, beware the filial son—
The dog’s bark warns of ghosts harming the furnace-tender.

**Fifty-Sixth Herb: Returning Cedar**
**Common Name:** Wise Mushroom
**Textual Name:** [None]
Warm in nature. Grows in Annan.

**Song:**
Vines spread, stems rise along jade-green streams,
Harvesters lose their way through the four seasons’ changes.
You must remember well, lest you err—
This is the ladder to Penglai, ten thousand leagues away.

**Fifty-Sixth Herb: Returning Cedar (continued)**
Shape like a cedar, purple in color. Treats perverse qi.

**Song:**
Vast and golden, it unfurls against the azure sky,
The purple Daoist inquires of mysteries profound.
If you would craft the returning elixir from this,
You must boil it through ten nights to see.

**Fifty-Seventh Herb: Golden Peach Vine**
**Common Name:** Lingering Fear
**Textual Name:** Single Man
Warm in nature. Grows in Hezhong Prefecture. Shape like a grapevine, trailing its tendrils.

**Song:**
Carved from green silk, it spreads its verdant hues,
The perfected one conceals it from the vulgar.
Boil it only in the waters of the Mystic River—
Mercury bewildered, gold seals twine in purple robes.

**Fifty-Eighth Herb: Earth [Missing Character]**
**Common Name:** Swallow Flower
**Textual Name:** [None]
Hot in nature. Grows in Huzhou. Leaf veins like a silkworm cocoon, the size of a thumb’s face. Treats epilepsy.

**Song:**
Leaf upon leaf, three by three, crimson against the boughs,
Most potent in the Way of the returning elixir.
Boil it in mercury for two watches of the night—
Then freely wield it to line the furnace’s fire-wall.

**Fifty-Ninth Herb: Slightly Red**
**Common Name:** Cliff-Piercing Cloth
**Textual Name:** Purple Heaven-Heaven, also called Martial Countenance Vermilion Mushroom
Cool in nature. Grows in the kingdom of Yutian.

**Sixtieth Herb: One Stem, One Leaf**
**Textual Name:** [None]
Leaf’s underside purple, stem likewise.
**Song:**
Beyond the bounds, it winds through forests and springs—
Must be simmered in the crucible.
Thrice boiled with eight stones,
How could the body not grow firm?

The preceding twenty-seven herbs:
Born in *ding-si*, die in *wu-ren*—
Harvest after the Winter Solstice.

**Sixty-First Herb: Dog’s-Tongue Vine**
**Common Name:** Fishweed
**Textual Name:** [None]
Cold in nature. Grows in Chenxu Prefecture.
Vines trail like a dog’s tongue. Treats snake venom.
**Song:**
Dog’s tongue, true to its name—
Vulgar folk and perfected ones call it by two.
Were this herb not of this world,
Crossing the river, filial piety would lack its power.

**Sixty-Second Herb: Jade Rampart**
**Common Name:** Foreigner’s Head
**Textual Name:** [None]
Cool in nature. Grows in Qiyong.
Flowers like bannered canopies, their tips purple.
Treats cholera.
**Song:**
Flowers like tattered banners, leaves like crimson silk—
North of the mountains, south of the river, each in dual form.
When gathering it, guard it well—
Let not outsiders know of the inner garden.

**Sixty-Third Herb: Jade Caltrop**
**Common Name:** Intercalary Mushroom
**Textual Name:** *Dui*
Cold in nature. Grows in Jinan.
Stems slender, leaves small, yellow in hue.
Treats heat-induced dysentery.
**Song:**

**Sixty-Third Herb: Crimson Tooth**
**Common Name:** [None]
**Textual Name:** *Single Tooth*
Warm in nature. Grows in Hexi Circuit.
Leaves like those of the mandarin orange, crimson in color, growing on rocks.
Treats floating convulsions.
**Song:**
Moon first rising o’er the cliff’s edge—
Carved for lords and Daoist robes alike.
Should the phoenix appear, it dances of itself—
No need for Jin courtiers to play their reed pipes.

**Sixty-Fourth Herb: Millet Gold**
**Common Name:** [None]
**Textual Name:** *Single Boat*
Cool in nature. Grows in Mian and Suizhou.
Stems slender, leaves pointed and round.
Treats all blood and qi disorders.
**Song:**
A noble immortal herb among men—
Yet mortals treat it as commonplace.
Were it simmered with golden sand by night,
One would know it outlives the tortoise’s years.

**Sixty-Fifth Herb: Purple Stone Amaranth**
**Common Name:** Cloud Garment
**Textual Name:** *Purple Canopy*
Hot in nature. Grows in Tongzhou.
Resembles amaranth with three veins.

**Treats bone paralysis.**
**Song:**
Through the threefold haze of *Tongzhi*—dim, dim—
Among elixirs, none surpass its power.
Not only does it lend a golden luster,
But in one night it transmutes yellow bronze.

**Sixty-Sixth Herb: Floating Perilla**
**Common Name:** Intertwined Silk
**Textual Name:** *Great Net*
Warm in nature. Grows in Yunzhou.
Resembles peas; its flowers and leaves treat blood dizziness.
**Song:**
Crimson shadows twine the traveler’s path—
Though found among men, it is not of this world.
Were the Heavenly Maiden Weizhen to see it,
She would surely pluck her skirts full.

**Sixty-Seventh Herb: Earth Smilax**
**Common Name:** River Grass
**Textual Name:** *Maiden’s Vine*
Warm in nature. Trailing vine with seeds.
Treats intestinal obstructions.
**Song:**
Green willows grace every secluded courtyard,
Yet few pluck from the dark river’s flow.
Plant it abundantly in your inner garden—
Guard the recipe, lest outsiders know.

**Sixty-Eighth Herb: Azurite**
**Common Name:** Belt Azure
**Textual Name:** *Barrier Channel*
Hot in nature. Grows in Shanzhou.
Trailing vine with pointed leaves.
Treats qi obstructions.
**Song:**
The Azure Emperor offers golden pills—
This divine water must be blended and consumed.
If placed within a green crucible,
Alas, the scattered snow melts before all eyes.

**Sixty-Ninth Herb: Profound Darkness**
**Common Name:** Stone Garment, also Fish Garment
**Textual Name:** *Supreme Cycle*
Hot in nature. Grows in Jiangling Prefecture, resembling stone lichen.
Treats cold qi.
**Song:**

Deep in profound darkness it grows upon stone,
Though present among men, none know its name.
Place but a trace within the great elixir—
At once, auspicious clouds gather beneath your feet.

The preceding ten herbs are born in *jia*-*ding*, die in *wu*-*ji*, and correspond to the Beginning of Autumn. Gather them twenty days after the Beginning of Summer.

**Seventieth Herb: Returning Year**
**Common Name:** Wooden Mutual Pearl
**Textual Name:** *Containing Purple*
Warm in nature. Grows in Kunlun.
Leaves like the elm, bearing pearls upon them.
Treats wind.
**Song:**
Heaven endures, earth abides, waters vast and flowing,
The numinous herb holds its pearl, its hue naturally fragrant.
Henceforth by the moonlit shores of the boundless sea,
It may be decocted and refined into nectar divine.

**Seventy-First Herb: Calendar Epoch**
**Common Name:** Southern Heaven
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Warm in nature. Grows in Fengxiang Prefecture.
Four-ridged stem, purple flowers, leaves small and pointed.
Treats all malign cold disorders.
**Song:**
Within Hongzhang Temple spring grasses grow,
Unlike those that fade when spring’s end brings the Calendar Epoch.
If blended within a white crucible,
Soon the nine snows scatter their radiant light.

**Seventy-Second Herb: Purple Gold Thatch**
**Common Name:** Even Mugwort
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Grows in Jiannan.
Purple-green stems, leaves long and pointed.
Treats heart pain.
**Song:**
Alone she walks, the verdant bride,
Never meet one born of Golden Flower’s distant courtyard.
Pluck and boil it upon golden ground—
From this moment, its name is known without smoke’s trace.

**Seventy-Third Herb: Purple Sea Toon**
**Common Name:** Intertwined Epoch
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Hot in nature. Grows in Jiangzhou.
Leaves like the *zhuang*, purple in hue, forming a tree.
Treats windstroke.
**Song:**

Together they gleam like golden caskets shadowing spring mountains,
Countless immortals hold and gaze upon them in hand.
One kind melts of itself to reveal its pattern,
Yet none compare to this one for refining the Golden Elixir.

**Seventy-Fourth Herb: Golden Micro**
**Common Name:** Double Gold
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Warm in nature. Grows in Jiannan.
Twines around rocks, leaves like *lei* onions, bearing seeds and roots.
Treats infantile malnutrition.
**Song:**
The Yang-separated bride loves the lingzhi fish,
Alone she sends ten thousand sheets of letters to the immortal elder.
Once she recognizes Golden Micro boiled with cold stone,
Her river chariot ascends, body borne into azure emptiness.

**Seventy-Fifth Herb: Purple Dream Minister**
**Common Name:** Village Epoch
**Textual Name:** Stone Knotweed (also recorded)
Grows in Hebei Circuit.
Purple in color.
Treats heart pain.
**Song:**
Flower Epoch faces the Qin River for ten thousand leagues,
Though born across ten thousand leagues, it refuses to speak.
If boiled together with the Three Rivers’ waters,
Its living form should tread the nine heavens’ sky.

**Seventy-Sixth Herb: Stone Mustard**
**Common Name:** Earth Flower
**Textual Name:** Southern Herb
Warm in nature. Grows in the capital.
Leaves like southern mustard greens.
Treats infantile fright.
**Song:**
The Purple Tenuity Heavenly Maiden does not cut cloth,
Yet she must ask mortals for Stone Mustard’s branches.
Avoid boiling it in a white-patterned crucible—
Instead, let cinnabar’s poison and mercury take flight.

**Seventy-Seventh Herb: Mountain Ridge**
**Common Name:** Ravine-Below Lingzhi
**Textual Name:** Never-Above Lingzhi
Cold in nature. Grows in Yizhou.
Leaves like *boleng* watergrass, forming clusters.
Treats wind disorders.
**Song:**
*Ding-ding*—the sound of woodcutting follows the crow,
*Miao-miao*—river waves, the grass naturally numinous.
Only Mountain Ridge is fit for careful gathering,
Where eight kinds of stone medicines naturally form.

**Seventy-Eighth Herb: Point-Tail Palm**
**Common Name:** Wind Grass
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Grows in Hengding Prefecture.
One leaf with three pointed tips.
Treats all malign sores.

**Seventy-Ninth Herb: Wang Qi**
**Common Name:** Green Heaven
**Textual Name:** No Celebration
Warm in nature. Grows in Jiangnan Circuit.
Leaves like *cheqian* (plantain), with striated stems.
Treats poisonous sores.
Grows readily north of the Wei Prefecture’s river—
where it thrives, people often dry it in the cold sun.
Boil it with five salts to form *yin’e*—
how then could one fail to live a long life?
**Song:**
*Dudu*—the Grand Treasury’s green elixir,
requires this numinous medium as its master.
Once this harmonized pulp is consumed,
before your eyes, ten thousand springs unfold.

**Eightieth Herb: Pointed Caltrop Vine**
**Common Name:** Great Pair
Grows in Jiannan.
Leaves like caltrop, trailing in vines.
Treats malign sores.
**Song:**
Mortals fail to grasp the gold elixir’s intent—
the pointed caltrop must become jade-medicine’s clay.
Not to mention how sulfur whitens,
it can also subdue arsenic within the crucible.

**Eighty-First Herb: Heaven’s Mandate Fulfilled**
**Common Name:** Having Destiny
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Grows in Zhong-Wanzhou.
Treats heat disorders; the rest goes unspoken.
**Song:**
The jade maidens of Yuyang Palace boil celestial pulp,
only when *Heaven’s Mandate Fulfilled* begins to fragrance.
It must guide mercury to open the path,
and serve as the courtyard wall for green elixir.

**Eighty-Second Herb: Facing-Heaven Grass**
**Common Name:** Ghost’s Urine Tube
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Grows in Tong-Hua Prefecture.

**Eighty-Second Herb: Facing-Heaven Grass (continued)**
Hollow-stemmed with nodes, long in growth.
Treats malign sores.
**Song:**
From afar, heaven’s shadow enters the void’s edge—
when grown in Tong-Hua, it carpets the market ground.
Behold the grass within the purple river chariot:
without it, the golden elixir’s work cannot abide.

**Eighty-Third Herb: Cicada’s Aid**
**Common Name:** Nine-Clan Elixir, also called *Jingtian*
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Grows in Yuyang County.
Leaves resemble plantain; vines trail with long roots.
Treats heat disorders.
**Song:**
Round upon round, myriad leaves sprout from orchid branches—
only in Yuyang does it flourish in season.
Buried west of the Three Palaces for October’s use,
then fit to enter the medicine, harmonizing the subtle.

**Eighty-Fourth Herb: Golden Lock of Heaven**
**Common Name:** Ashen Goosefoot
**Textual Name:** Falling Goosefoot
Warm in nature. Grows in Ba-Nan.
Leaves small and square, reddish.
Treats rising qi.
**Song:**
Golden Heaven’s surplus, rendered to ash,
must blend with yellow sprouts to form the clay.
From this, mercury must be subdued—
this alone is the ladder to the returning elixir’s path.

**Eighty-Fifth Herb: Returning Phoenix Vine**
**Common Name:** Heaven’s Mother
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Warm in nature. Grows in Meiyuan County.
Vines trail with three leaves.
Treats blood dizziness.
**Song:**
A thousand fathoms up the mountain stones, across the plains—
since ancient times, people have passed down its origin in Meiyuan.

**Eighty-Sixth Herb: Uniting Yang Water Chestnut**
**Common Name:** Purslane
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature.
Leaves round, texture slippery.
Treats intestinal heat.
Grows in Danfang Prefecture.
**Song:**
Soft tendrils trail across Danfang,
fit to join the returning elixir’s domain.
Mercury dare not take the lead—
vainly chasing cinnabar, lost in the crucible.

**Eighty-Seventh Herb: Uniting Yang Amaranth**
**Common Name:** Human Amaranth
**Textual Name:** Knotted Needle
Cold in nature.
Grows in foreign lands.
Leaves pointed.
Treats gan disorders.
**Song:**
Harmonizing spirit and ordering the po, it emits silver light,
this stone-drug pouch forming one method.
Today, the jade pestle advances by the chart—
it too can subdue the Four Spirit Frosts.

**Eighty-Eighth Herb: Uniting the Great Heaven**
**Common Name:** Red Salt Flower, also called Celebration Reed
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Warm in nature.
Grows in Yizhou.
Leaves narrow and pointed, flowers like brambles.
Treats blood and qi.
**Song:**
In the Uniting the Great Palace, Uniting the Great Heaven,
burned to ash and boiled in cold springs.
Yang ren cannot pass this ash—
yin gui must ultimately fly away as smoke.

**Eighty-Ninth Herb: Hibiscus Boat**
**Common Name:** Rice Sack
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cool in nature.
Grows in Qiannan.

**Eighty-Ninth Herb: Hibiscus Boat (continued)**
Leaves verdant, flowers bearing seeds.
Treats malign heat and oppression.
**Song:**
Into the azure vastness, deep into the unseen,
only the flower-boat reaches the Dao’s corner.
Though root and sprout are boiled with herbs as one,
this stone alone sinks while the rest naturally float.

The preceding twenty herbs:
Born in *wu-ren* years, die in *ding-ji* years.
Gathered at the *Beginning of Summer* or forty days before the *Beginning of Autumn*.

**Ninetieth Herb: Unchanging Spring**
**Common Name:** Kunlun Mallow
**Textual Name:** Purple Pestle
Grows in the Western Heaven.
Leaves round with angles, flowers purple.
Treats oil convulsions.
**Song:**
Planted alone atop the loftiest crag,
it blooms in courtyards among mortals.
When the returning elixir’s reckoning is met,
how could sulfur fail to yield to its ash?

**Ninety-First Herb: Fox-Grandson Vine**
**Common Name:** Earth Coin
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Hot in nature.
Grows in the farthest south.
Vines trailing, leaves pointed, branches resonant.
Treats malign sores.
**Song:**
Far-reaching vines coil round the Celestial Ford,
growing till the south wind blows, never knowing spring.
Brought in the third month to court the Emperor’s will,
it would make the living body tread the azure scales.

**Ninety-Second Herb: Stone Channel**
**Common Name:** Lower Fish Herb
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature.
Grows in Kaitong Prefecture.
Leaves like bamboo, flowers yellow.
Treats childhood *gan* disorders.
**Song:**
In the jade-flower grotto, the river fish unfurls,
the fairest model among ten thousand herbs.
When it cures purple cinnabar to a lustrous yellow,
it also washes green cinnabar till its red fades.

The preceding three herbs:
Born in *wu-ding* years, die in *jia-yi* years.
Gathered at the *Beginning of Winter* or twenty days thereafter.

**Ninety-Third Herb: Fish-Gut Vine**
**Common Name:** Spirit Flower
**Textual Name:** Bramble Pear
Warm in nature.
Grows in Xuanzhou and Hebei.
Leaves like horse purslane, bearing brambles.
Treats malign sores.
**Song:**

**Ninety-Third Herb: Fish-Gut Vine (continued)**
One asks, "Is there a medicine like fish-gut?"
It resolves and restores the elixir, fine for formulas.
In the three cauldrons’ smoke, auspicious hues unfold;
in the Nine Heavens’ palace, numinous fragrance abides.

**Ninety-Fourth Herb: Mountain Chrysanthemum**
**Common Name:** True Floating Man
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature.
Grows in Weinan County.
Leaves like tea, flowers like chrysanthemum.
Treats wine-induced heart palpitations.
**Song:**
Flowers like yellow chrysanthemum, leaves like tea,
the common folk know not its immortal lineage.
It can restore green cinnabar’s complexion,
and turn rouge powder to golden ivory.

**Ninety-Fifth Herb: Single Perfection**
**Common Name:** Shepherd’s Purse
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Grows in Henan Prefecture.
Hot in nature.
Leaves like lotus, grows near water.
Treats snakebite.
**Song:**
Heavenly perfection, earthly truth—all from man,
yet common mortals fail to recognize the real.
From this, the Eight Spirits willingly accept death,
while mortals henceforth escape as dust.

**Ninety-Sixth Herb: Golden Mirror Cold**
**Common Name:** Human Fungus
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Grows in Annan Prefecture.
Resembles mallow, bears hair.
Treats insect and snake venom.
**Song:**
Born in autumn on stone and stone alike,
leaves with hair, stems with crimson specks.
Beyond the Three Conjunctions, several forms appear—
of all, the finest hails from the Eastern Capital.

**Ninety-Seventh Herb: Green Branch**
**Common Name:** Bitter Awakening Wood
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Grows in West Long Prefecture.
Cold in nature.
Matures into a tree with branches.
Treats beriberi.
**Song:**
A full-grown tree with branches spans ten thousand mountains,
planted by the Queen of the West among mortals.
It refines green vitriol without foul qi,
and preserves the luster of purple gold.

**Ninety-Eighth Herb: Purple Tower Spring**
**Common Name:** White Horse Herb
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Also called Lingering Jasmine.
Leaves purple, green, and pointed.
Grows in Jiangzhou.
**Song:**

**Purple Tower Spring (continued)**
**Song:**
In grandeur blooms the Purple Tower Spring,
alone it claims the mortal world’s white-backed scales.
To refine the returning elixir, one must add boiling,
to ascend the azure heavens and attain the Ninefold Perfected.

**Ninety-Ninth Herb: Heaven-Supporting Terrace**
**Common Name:** Back-Vinegar Wood
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Warm in nature, matures into a tree bearing fruit.
Grows in Mount Zhongnan.
Treats regurgitation.
**Song:**
Towering tall, the tree grows on Southern Mountain,
among ten thousand woods, this one is most worthy.
When the celestial medicine is fired, a surplus must remain—
it revives the living body, restoring white bones whole.

**One Hundredth Herb: Sturdy Metal Bone**
**Common Name:** Green Fish Marsh
**Textual Name:** Celestial Pattern Taro
Warm in nature.
Resembles cogongrass, bears fruit.
Treats fetal leakage.
**Song:**
Sparse leaves spread like cogongrass,
each year the Perfected One waters it with jade dew.
It grants the returning elixir wings to grow,
and those who consume it ascend to the azure heavens.

**One Hundred First Herb: Wood Melon**
**Common Name:** Heaven-Union Fruit
**Song:**
Swaying, the celestial tree grows in southern Ba,
its sunlit blossoms lush, held each day.
When the great medicine is compounded, it must be split abundantly—
only after autumn’s harvest is it fit for use.

**One Hundred Second Herb: Scattered Dew Herb**
**Common Name:** No-Green
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature, grows in Bazhou.
A cluster of three or two leaves, laden with dew.
Treats epidemic diseases.
**Song:**
A cluster of flowers with scattered leaves,
known for its goodness yet unnamed among men.
Behold—when the medicine is wrought, its golden hue is fair,
and those who gather it with incantations startle ghosts and gods.

The preceding ten herbs:
born in *wuzi*, die in *jiasi*,
correspond to the advent of autumn,
and are gathered after the Summer Solstice, before and after the Beginning of Winter.

**103: Yellow Emperor’s Spring**
**Common Name:** Hibiscus Water
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Its flowers vary between purple and yellow, growing around water. Treats poisonous winds.

**Song:**
Though beams and pillars serve a house’s frame,
the Way of Returning Elixir needs hibiscus water.
If one speaks of the finest from the Queen Mother of the West,
gathered from Southern Mountain, its use is all-encompassing.

**104: Mountain Turbidity**
**Common Name:** Water Turbidity
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Each stem bears three leaves, resembling *shuòyì*. Treats wind-blood disorders.

**Song:**
Jade towers open mirrors to reflect three mountains,
this herb’s birth is no ordinary matter.
If not upon the lofty peaks of rocky summits,
then it must grow nurtured by cliffside springs.

**105: Autumn’s End Record**
**Common Name:** White Luxuriant Tree
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Grows into a tree with willow-like leaves. Found on roads beyond the mountain passes. Treats all malign sores.

**Song:**
The sky stretches long, the moon hangs in azure vastness,
the moon stands before a thousand mountains and ten thousand herbs.
When gathering and compounding medicine, take heed—
pluck and simmer it together with yellow sprouts.

**106: Floating Forest Pool**
**Common Name:** Earth’s Wrinkle
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Leaves resemble willow but are wrinkled. Hot in nature. Treats cold winds.

**Song:**
Jade Pool’s waters, cold and clear, mirror heaven’s heart,
this herb’s worth could rival gold in price.
When paired with sulphur, they grasp each other tight—
best of all for guiding lead and *ren*’s flight.

**107: Crane’s Arrival Branch**
**Common Name:** Female Chastetree
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Effective for treating cholera.

**Song:**
Level and boundless, heaven and earth press near,
yet depths beyond Dragon Gate outmeasure the sea.
This immortal herb grows as a tree among men—
unrecognized, it buries itself in obscurity.

**108: Mountain Purple Perilla**
**Common Name:** Jiezhou Greens
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Found in Shezhou and Xuanzhou. Stems purple, leaves like true purple perilla. Cold in nature.

**Song:**
In jade depths, profound waves arise,
this fine herb’s seeds resemble silk.
With cinnabar from Danyang, it banishes black hues—
ground with stone, it turns pure as snow.

**109: Harmonizing Spirit Mushroom**
**Common Name:** Returning Bone
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Found in Zhongwanzhou. Resembles *ju* trees. Effective for treating consumption and manic madness.

**Song:**
The world already holds the herb of returning cinnabar,
yet cast aside, it refuses to be consumed.
Though born only to die again,
how pitiful—this immortal herb left to idle.

**110: Fragrant Rue Guide**
**Common Name:** Cottonwood
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Grows in Maozhou. Warm in nature. Becomes a tree with cotton inside. Treats blood stagnation and qi obstruction.

**Song:**
The Dao levels the paths of heaven’s wandering,
yet common folk fail to learn its ways.
If you take this and boil it with mercury,
how could white clouds not gather before your eyes?

**111: Cliff Indigo**
**Common Name:** Trough-Attaching Grass
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Bitter in taste, toxic. One leaf with many points, like *jin* grass. Treats white wind.

**Song:**
Gold forged like jade, fire’s sand,
this herb’s numinous power acts as a fang.
Its nature shares a root with woman and fire—
only because it refuses to submit to the river chariot.

**112: Startled Dragon’s Return**
**Common Name:** Camphorwood
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Toxic. Leaves as wide as three fingers, grows into a tree. Found near Hanshan in Mengxiazhou. Treats ghostly infestations.

**Song:**
Though kindred to the tree in form and grain,
Zhang Qian rode the azure clouds to bring it here.
This tree, once past a thousand years of age,
parts every river’s course as though by its own might.

The preceding ten herbs: born on *jia-ren* days, wither on *wu-ren* days. Harvest them at the advent of the Beginning of Winter, or around the Spring and Autumn Equinoxes.

**113: Purple Chicken’s Intestines**
**Common Name:** Water Vine
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Warm in nature. Found in the Jiangnan Circuit. Grows near water, trailing in vines. Treats paralysis and numbness.

**Song:**
Where emerald streams arise in distant, quiet pools,
later adepts lose their way in search of truth.
When *ren-gui* days grow hard, boil it well—
if left past two nights, it softens like mud.

**114: Longevity’s Embrace**
**Common Name:** Wintergreen
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Warm in nature. Found in the Hebei Circuit. Leaves evergreen, grows into a tree with fruit. Treats fractures and injuries.

**Song:**
Through four seasons, unchanging beneath the jade-hued clouds,
it harmonizes with the returning elixir as one family.
Though men of old consumed it for millennia in vain,
how much less could it serve mercury as the river chariot?

**115: Reed-Mouth Cold**
**Common Name:** Heroic Mushroom
**Textual Name:** *Fengyi*
Cold in nature. Found in Yun’an. Leaves round, stems small. Treats windstroke.

**Song:**
Round as the heavens and earth, shaped like an egg,
this numinous herb, this immortal formula, grows from the earth.
Such a treasure could save the mortal world—
today, it is cherished only in the immortals’ scriptures.

**116: Silk-Bearing Gold**
**Common Name:** Tallow Tree
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Found in Mian and Jianzhou. Hangs in golden threads. Treats blocked menstruation in women.

**Song:**
Ten thousand strands descend like green-gold silk,
yet this immortal herb remains unknown to men.
Only when mercury’s body endures the flame
must it be refined a hundred times to enter the subtle mystery.

**117: Guarding Niter**
**Common Name:** Dissolving Bamboo Grass
**Textual Name:** *Caogou Zhi*
Hot in nature. Found in Guangzhou. Leaves round as fingers, with stems. Prepares against noxious cold and poison.

**Song:**
Amid the thousand mists of the Three Gorges,
this cold herb takes form in Guangzhou.
In the smoke of the eight minerals, it is father and son;
in the heavens above, it bears many names.

**118: Imperial Wine-Soberer**
**Common Name:** Cinnabar Mushroom
**Textual Name:** *Lou Chun Grass*
Cold in nature. Found in the Henan Circuit. Three flowers, leaves green. Treats heart pain.

**Song:**
Why does this blue-cinnabar dissolve wine’s grip?
The numinous herb must first be boiled through the night.
From now on, drink deeply—drunkenness will fade,
especially when plucked and burned in the fire.

**119: Jade-Enveloping Mushroom**
**Common Name:** Floating Water Indigo
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Found in the Lingwai Circuit. Like small indigo, leaves long and pointed. Treats lung paralysis.

**Song:**
Row upon row, it rises by the stream in verdant shoots,
its power unyielding, equal to the eight minerals.
In every crucible, only a pinch is needed—
else, like all things, it must be burned in the fire.

**120: Lute Mushroom**
**Common Name:** Hanger-On
**Textual Name:** *Baitian*
Cold in nature. Found in Yunnan. Leaves round and long, bearing seeds. Treats severe wind.

**121: Earth-Simmered Vine**
**Common Name:** Great Jade
**Textual Name:** *Laohan*
Cold in nature. Found in Bazhong Prefecture. Leaves with three points, trailing vines. Treats wind diseases.

**Song:**
Only when lush does one know it grows on Heaven’s Terrace—
it must be drawn with green salt to yield white sap.
If smoke lingers yet fails to rise above the embers,
then this vine must be planted to make a fence.

**122: Bronze-Hoof Vine**
**Common Name:** Supreme Jade Mushroom
**Textual Name:** *Linzhi*
Cold in nature. Found in Qin Chuan. Leaves long and pointed, trailing vines. Treats wind malignities.

**Song:**
The Queen Mother of the East wanders amid clouds and rain,
yet the Bronze-Hoof Vine refuses to grow.
Only when Your Majesty gathers it in Qin Chuan—
and when gathering, never speak its name beforehand.

**123: Barbarian Gold Toxin**
**Common Name:** Miasma-Heaven Tree
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Toxic. Found in Yunnan. Treats snake venom.
The tree stands no taller than three feet; its leaves are pointed, and its broken sap is lethal.

**Song:**
When yin and yang fail to merge, this tree is born—
its poisonous branches refuse to grow tall.
Boil it in the second *hai* hour by the river’s edge,
and you will know how yin’s *gui* dissolves without flame.

**124: River-Seeking Herb**
**Common Name:** River Wind
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Found in southern Qian. The sprouts grow several yards long. Treats joy-sickness.

**Song:**
The vast sea stretches a thousand myriad leagues—
how could this herb’s search be twice as long?
Only Zhang Qian would know where to find it,
but when gathering, never decoct it with salt.

**125: Essence Mushroom**
**Common and Textual Names:** None recorded
Yellow-white in color, without stem or stalk, unaligned with the seasons, and does not treat illness.

**Song:**
When it sprouts in spring, it is mostly yellow-white;
when it sprouts in summer or autumn, it bears black and green.
Only ask Dongfang Shuo before the palace hall—
he knows both its place and its name.

**126: Stone Channel**
**Common Name:** Cold Bamboo Herb
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Kills parasites. Found in southern Jing. Resembles bamboo sprouts, long in growth.

**Song:**

**Song:**
Its emerald roots spread across earth and sky,
its power settles the po and anchors the hun.
Wherever planted in the third month’s season,
that household’s descendants shall prosper.

**127: Wild Lotus**
**Common Name:** Tray Herb
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Found in Huainan Circuit. Leaves as large as platters, bearing rootlets.

**Song:**
Its whole body grows and thrives by the streamside—
summon Zhang Qian to ask of its native land.
Once gathered, chop root and stem together,
and it can boil white the foulest cinnabar sores.

**128: Gold-Encrusted Branch**
**Common Name:** Red Sandalwood
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Warm in nature. Found in Lingnan. The tree casts a golden sheen. Treats the five kinds of snake venom.

**Song:**
Layer upon layer, gold upon golden sheen,
this tree is rarely met with among men.
When your servant reached Mount Ao’s northern face,
the Perfected One himself bestowed the dark gong.

**129: Earth Vein**
**Common Name:** Thorn Taro
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature, found in the Five Lakes. Leaves and roots each a foot long. Treats all heat illnesses.

**Song:**
Warm and cool, sun and moon soak the boundless sky,
fine herbs fill the fields of the human realm.
Add but a pinch among the Eight Stones—
forever shall your golden bones endure.

**130: Golden Sheen Copper**
**Common Name:** Boxwood
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Found in Maozhou. Can treat leprosy.

**Song:**
Amid the thriving forests of myriad trees,
only this one pierces the sage’s discerning eye.
When you seek to gather it, the Jade Dragon enters—
do not treat it as common or take it lightly.

**131: Deep Pool Grass**
**Common Name:** Chin-Rest Heaven
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Found in Jinzhou.

**131: Deep Pool Grass (continued)**
Leaves fine, stems long, color blue-green tinged with yellow. Treats shivering cold.

**Song:**
Subtle grasses cluster by the quiet stream,
drooping leaves and slender shoots beside the water’s edge.
Countless immortals have consumed and ascended—
once bestowed by parents upon the wife of Right Army.

**132: Purple Palace**
**Common Name:** Frost-Bearing Flower
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Found in Hebei Circuit. Leaves the size of a palm, purple stems. Treats scorching heat.

**Song:**
Jade Yang Palace maidens play at hidden hooks,
the Purple Palace conceals its form, its shape withdrawn.
Having flown to the Nine Heavens’ celestial court,
the immortal scriptures transcribed remain to this day.

**133: Wuyang Seed**
**Common Name:** Sky-Connecting Grass
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Warm in nature. Found on Kunlun. Shoots long, leaves fine. Treats bone paralysis.

**Song:**
Delicate Wuyang grass, its seedlings stretch to avoid the spring wind.
Among great medicines, its efficacy is most profound—
meet water and you must not delay.

**134: Pointed Jade**
**Common Name:** Human Longevity
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Leaves large as a hand, resembling plantain. Treats horse ringworm.

**Song:**
Winding through lake streams into the Tian Mountains,
shoots rise several feet, leaves pointed and round.
A slice of white gold, like frost abiding—
is this not a numinous fragrance, yet how can it be whole?

**135: Moonless Ganoderma**
**Common Name:** Germ-Free
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Warm in nature. Found throughout the world. Color purple-red, stemless. Treats malignant sores.

**Song:**
Yin and Yang’s abundant qi naturally engenders it,
unbound by the moon’s duality of light and dark.
It can suppress and subdue mercury—
the Yang King shall then lose his tender affection.

**136: Sea Passage**
**Common Name:** Face Ganoderma
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Warm in nature. Found beyond the mountain ranges. Leaves like white *tongbei*. Regulates menstrual irregularities.

**Song:**

**137: Wu Net Grass**
**Common Name:** None recorded in common texts
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Toxic in nature. Found in the Jiang-Huai region. Grows into a tree, leaves like two fingers. Treats *zanpan*.

**Song:**
Leaf upon leaf, life-generating like the moon,
ingesting it restores one’s root—becoming an immortal.
Moreover, when refined with the returning elixir,
how could golden bones not be made whole?

The Empress Dowager of the former dynasty commanded its gathering,
but after her reign, none sought it again.
Do not speak of its use within the golden elixir—
if known to others, it would be prized beyond gold.

**138: Wu Pear Reed**
**Common Name & Textual Name:** Identical
Warm in nature. Found in Jiangnan. Vines extend with branches. Treats metal-inflicted wounds.

**Song:**
Lush vines trail, leaves like rattan,
most skillful in mercury, versatile in function.
Pounded thin, it fails—boil it further,
then it softens, pliable as a rope.

**139: Wu Millet Vine**
**Common Name:** Interval Ganoderma
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Warm in nature, toxic. Found in Yunnan. Slender leaves with seeds. Treats *leng* disease.

**Song:**

**140: Rao Ya Huan**
**Common Name:** Lue Shao Sprout
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Found in Shu. Vines extend with seeds. Treats leaking sores.

**Song:**
Golden petals tangled with jade blossoms,
Wu and Shu each yield two kinds.
When gathering, take care—
do not let the sunlight slant.

**140: Rao Ya Huan (alternate entry)**
**Song:**
The Sacred Emperor’s heavenly maiden,
by this spirit herb ascended to heaven.
Now that you know the Three Perfected Grasses,
you shall surely meet the ancient Xihe’s chariot.

**141: Golden Flower Boat**
**Common Name:** Worshipping Woman’s Ganoderma
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Found in Weinan. Pointed leaves, long stems. Treats all wind disorders.

**Song:**
Layered red leaves embrace the azure void,
ten thousand blossoms bloom from the earth.
When gathering, consult Master Fangshuo—
only you must not offend the spirits.

**142: Rao He Gong**
**Common Name:** Red Willow
**Textual Name:** None recorded
Cold in nature. Found in Zizhou. Tree-like. Also treats accumulations and hard masses.

**Song:**
The immortal praised the seeds of Mount Tiantai,
each year the Perfected One secretly commands their opening.
Fangshuo took some home last year—
why did he not present them when summoned?

**143: Wang Grass**
**Common Name & Textual Name:** None recorded

**Toxic in nature.** Found in Shu lands. Grows into a tree; leaves as wide as two fingers. Treats sores and ringworm.

**Song:**
The immortal herb grows in distant lands,
journeying alongside the returning elixir.
Unlike other remedies with lustrous hues,
it alone harmonizes well with mercury’s nature.

**144: Li Lu**
**Common Name:** None recorded in texts.
**Warm in nature.** Found in Shu. Has trailing vines. Its bark treats metal-inflicted wounds.

**Song:**
Deep within the sacred mountains it dwells,
born where sun and moon shine through.
As an assistant to the cinnabar,
even cinnabar itself dare not contend.

**145: Xu Sui Grass**
**Common Name:** Questioning Ganoderma
**Textual Name:** None recorded
**Toxic in nature.** Slender leaves with seeds. Treats cold disorders.

**Song:**
The earth spans a thousand rivers wide,
the mountains cradle a hundred herbs divine.
From here to the Nine Heavens’ height,
on the mountain’s edge, the Jade Capital shines.

**146: Bai Luo Pin**

**Textual Name:** Purple Fan

**147: Qing Tian Xin**
**Common Name:** White Lofty
**Textual Name:** Single Mugwort
**Cool in nature.** Found in Khotan. Leaves resemble mugwort, with three lobes forming branches; flowers are greenish-yellow. Born in *jia-wu* (wood-earth) years, withers in *ding-ren* (fire-water) years. **Treats internal injuries.** Harvest before the White Dew solar term, after the Start of Autumn. *Song:*
*Not tall, leaves like oil’s sheen,*
*Ever on high peaks, ridge tops unseen.*
*Though born when spring’s first breath is true,*
*Its power waits till autumn’s due.*

**148: Feng Huang Ke**
**Common Name:** Mountain Bamboo
**Textual Name:** Snow-Bearing Countenance
**Cold in nature.** Found in Southern India. Leaves resemble bamboo, branches like wood, tips like scallions; flowers are purple. Born in *jia-ding* (wood-fire) years, withers in *wu-ji* (earth-earth) years. **Treats proliferating sores.** Harvest before the Limit of Heat solar term, after the Start of Summer. *Song:*
*Leaves like winter bamboo cling to cliffs so steep,*
*In gardens too, or courts where mortals keep.*
*Flowers purple-red, inconstant bloom,*
*Yet radiant glory fills all seasons’ gloom.*

**149: Chi Luo Teng**
**Common Name:** Red Apple Grass
**Textual Name:** Earth’s Heart
**Cold in nature, bitter in taste.** Shape resembles paulownia leaves, color purple-red. Found in Silla. **Treats inverted sores.** Born in *wu-ren* (earth-water) years, withers in *ding-gui* (fire-water) years. Harvest before the Lesser Cold solar term, after the Start of Spring. *Song:*
*Leaves like red silk twine round balustrades,*
*On mountain peaks or courts where light pervades.*
*To fade, cast it in ninefold streams—*
*There, in the waters, its spirit gleams.*

**150: Bai Luan Xiang**
**Common Name:** Three-Leaf Grass
**Textual Name:** Purple Remnant
**Harmonizes with all medicines.** Found in Central India. Leafless, with three leaves. Born in *wu-geng* (earth-metal) years. **Treats consumptive illnesses.** Harvest before the Grain in Ear solar term, after the Start of Autumn. *Song:*
*Vines unfurl three leaves, so slender, slight,*
*Half by the pool, half on the rocky height.*
*To know it, boil in sunlit hours,*
*Then refine by moon to salt’s pure powers.*

**151: Sao Tian Yu**
**Common Name:** Azure-Stem Ganoderma
**Textual Name:** Silk-Patterned Grass
**Cold in nature.** Found in Ruizhou. Leaves like fingerprints, growing several *chi* tall. Born in *jia-wu* (wood-earth) years, withers in *bing-ding* (fire-fire) years. **Treats water diseases.** Harvest before the Start of Winter solar term, after the Winter Solstice. *Song:*
*By streams, its veins like silk in crimson script,*
*Year after year, its leaves turn verdant, stripped.*
*When plucking, heed the taboos well,*
*Lest water’s essence break the spell.*

**152: Feng Zhen Ren**
**Common Name:** Water Knot
**Textual Name:** Yellow Bramble
**Hot in nature.** Found in Daizhou. Leaves green with seeds. Born in *jia-ding* (wood-fire) years, withers in *gui-ji* (water-earth) years. *Song:*
*Flowers like gold unfurl on mountains wide,*
*Leaves in three blades, as if by scissors tied.*
*When quicksilver’s life is sealed anew,*
*It crafts the Great Return’s elixir true.*

**153: Heaven’s Circlet Zhi**
**Common Name:** Stone Willow
**Textual Name:** Earth Zhi
**Hot in nature.** Found in Longyou. Resembles a willow, several *chi* tall. **Treats toothache.** Harvest after the Cold Dew solar term, before Minor Heat. *Song:*
*Stem upon stem, white, clinging to cliffs,*
*Leaf upon leaf, arrayed beside blossoms.*
*Place a pinch by green-watered pools—*
*From this, the Azure Elixir sheds all dust.*

**154: Water Peach**
**Common Name:** Green-Red
**Textual Name:** Heroic Zhi
**Warm in nature.** Found on Mount Lu in Jiangzhou. Born in *wu-ding* (earth-fire) years, withers in *geng-ji* (metal-earth) years. Resembles a peach, grows near water. **Treats paralysis and spasms.** Harvest after the Great Cold solar term, before the Spring Equinox. *Song:*
*Wondrous zhi, rare herb of sacred peaks,*
*Its trunk stands by winding stream and spring.*
*Best used to disperse water’s qi with its bloom—*
*Gather it only when spring’s warmth is full.*

**155: Subtle Fragrance**
**Common Name:** Stone Marrow
**Textual Name:** Earth Subtlety
**Cold in nature.** Found in Hunan.

**155: Subtle Fragrance (continued)**
Leaves small, flowers delicate. Born in *wu-ding* (earth-fire) years, withers in *jia-yi* (wood-wood) years. **Treats chest and diaphragm heat-qi.** Harvest after the Start of Autumn solar term, before the Limit of Heat. *Song:*
*Clustered fine leaves, tiny blossoms arrayed,*
*On level slopes or cliffs they are laid.*
*Like grass from Queen Mother’s western bower,*
*Examine the stem—slender as a hairpin’s power.*

**156: Verdant Layers**
**Common Name:** Layered Terrace Grass
**Textual Name:** Bramble Shadow
**Warm in nature.** Found in Longyou. Leaves small and layered. Born in *bing-ding* (fire-fire) years, withers in *geng-ji* (metal-earth) years. **Treats malignant sores.** Harvest after the Grain in Ear solar term, before the Start of Spring. *Song:*
*Leaves bearing fruit hold the greatest might,*
*Heaven and earth share this same sight.*
*When gathering, keep it pure and bright—*
*For ease in use, align with *zhun-meng’s* light.*

**157: Mountain Brocade Zhi**
**Common Name:** Mountain Cloud Terrace
**Textual Name:** Nine-Hole Vegetable
**Cold in nature.** Found in Xianyang. Branches and leaves resemble *yuntai*. Born in *jia-ding* (wood-fire) years, withers in *mao-you* (wood-metal) years. **Treats all heat-winds.** Harvest after the Winter Solstice, before the Waking of Insects. *Song:*
*Branches coil where mountain mists entwine,*
*By cliffs or pools they softly shine.*
*If in flowers they’re boiled awhile,*
*Their taste reveals a sweetness mild.*

**158: Threaded Gold Cold**
**Common Name:** Purple Stone Duckweed
**Textual Name:** River Qi
**Warm in nature.** Toxic. Found on Mount Zhongnan. Leaves like *wei*, stems purple. Born in *wu-ding* (earth-fire) years, withers in *yi-gui* (wood-water) years. **Treats qi-swelling.** Harvest after the Start of Autumn, before the Start of Winter. *Song:*
*Moonlight on golden towers guides the true,*
*The third pool’s depths hold spirits anew.*
*Just at Start of Winter’s turn,*
*Gather when cranes’ cries cease to burn.*

**159: Cowrie Purple**
**Common Name:** Wind Stone Vine
**Textual Name:** Earth Oil
**Cold in nature.** Found on White Horse Mountain. Leaves round, vines trailing. Born in *jia-yi* (wood-wood) years, withers in *wu-ji* (earth-earth) years. **Treats acute exhaustion.** Harvest after the Lesser Cold solar term, before the Spring Equinox. *Song:*
*Vines spread, round leaves in rows align,*
*By cliffside springs they softly twine.*
*Though Eight Stones may seem of no worth,*
*Grind with green lotus for rebirth.*

**160: Crane Spring Zhi**
**Common Name:** Crow’s-Foot Chicken Grass
**Textual Name:** Fine Zhi Grass
**Hot in nature.** Found in Jingzhou. Leaves small, stems slender. Born in *wu-ren* (earth-water) years, withers in *jia-yi* (wood-wood) years. **Treats chronic diarrhea.** Harvest after the Summer Solstice, before the Lesser Heat. *Song:*
*Slender stems with leaves so slight,*
*By waterside they catch the light.*
*When summer’s heat begins to wane,*
*Gather then to ease the pain.*

**161: Stone Joint Zhi**
**Common Name:** Cold Seed
**Textual Name:** Embracing Spring
**Hot in nature.** Found in Lantian County. Leaves large and pointed, stems purple with nodes. Born in *gui-ji* (water-earth) years, withers in *zi-wu* (water-fire) years. **Treats heart pain.** Harvest after the White Dew solar term, before the Beginning of Winter. *Song:*
*Leaves like mulberry, stems like joints,*
*Loving to grow on lofty cliffs’ heights.*
*If brought among men to repel ghosts,*
*It can also in heaven subdue spirits.*

**The preceding entries correspond to solar terms, the Six Jia cycles, and the numinous subtleties of cold and heat.**

**162: Stone Toon Zhi**
**Common Name:** Scenic Zhi
**Textual Name:** Yellow Wind
Found in the Jiangnan Circuit. **Treats heart vomiting and counterflow.** *Song:*
*Vines extend from branch to branch by cliffs,*
*With ocean veins’ flow, its taste bears salt.*
*A myriad herbs of Ziyang, heaven’s grass—*
*Fit to boil with mortal red salt.*

**163: Stone Pepper Vine Zhi**
**Common Name:** Nine Fields
**Textual Name:** Heavenly Circumference
Found in Beizhou. **Treats paralysis and wilting.** *Song:*
*Carved like the Queen Mother’s skirt sash,*
*Slender stems from immortals’ abode.*
*When gathering, purity must be kept—*
*Still fear the golden shadow slanting west.*

**163: Stone Pepper Vine Zhi (continued)**
*Song:*
*Vines stretch far into the celestial net,*
*Later immortals, gather without disdain.*
*Harvest at dawn, at noon—beware the storm,*
*No need to cross the river’s waves again.*

**164: Crane-Chanting Branch**
**Common Name:** Stone Leaf
**Textual Name:** Wenlu

*Song:*
*Dragon’s zhi and phoenix’s plume from wondrous peaks,*
*Dwelling by moonlit sands near cliffside heights.*
*Born where willow catkins drift in empty light,*
*Mix with mercury and boil with salt just right.*

*Slender stems and tiny leaves of verdant hue,*
*Known by two names—one celestial, one earthly true.*
*This plant shifts unseen through all four seasons’ span,*
*Most potent when gathered as blossoms begin.*

**166: Purple Gold Bloom**
**Common Name:** Stone Heart
**Textual Name:** Fish Leaf

Found in Luozhou. **Leaves round with purple undersides.** *Treats malignant sores.*
*Born under Jia and Ji, wither under Wu and Ren.*
*Gather after the Spring Equinox, seek before the Start of Summer.*
*Song:*
*When mortals ask of this herb’s name,*
*Its leaves are round with crimson specks like shells.*
*Boiled as in the darkest depths’ alchemy,*
*Even sinking stones will rise and float as well.*

**167: Sun Water Mint**
**Common Name:** Supreme Peace
**Textual Name:** None recorded
**Nature:** Warm
Found in Chenxu Prefecture.

**167: Sun Water Mint (continued)**
**Leaves resemble perilla, stems purple.** *Treats all types of coughs.*
*Song:*
*Leaves cut like gold’s base, wrinkled with golden light,*
*Growing by perennial streams of emerald green.*
*Only when true adepts come to gather and refine,*
*Do soft robes grace the halls of Purple Yang’s abode.*

chunks.original_text: 蓬莱山西灶还丹歌 经名：蓬莱山西灶还丹歌。 原题汉黄玄锺撰。 但书中官名、地名及歌词文体音出唐代。 当系唐人伪托。 原本一卷，徒分作二卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞神部众街类。 蓬莱山西灶还丹歌卷上 汉检校仆射金紫光禄大夫黄玄锺撰 臣闻鹪鹩在木，不逾一枝之巢。 偃鼠饮河，无过一肠之满。 伏惟陛下名逾东户，调美南风，在於兆民，无不咸止。 何重万乘之荣，而轻不死之道。 臣伏以元封年奉诏蓬莱，亲求妙术，经过海难，涉历幽阳，不惮危亡，而求至道。 先是，皇恩远责，以感微臣尽忠，得遇大仙，躬赐灵药，极诚进上。 何谓陛下安听佞臣，信为祆诈，赐臣自饵。 臣俄别皇庭，不胜悲望，游宫未遍，少许十年，恐虑从容，自为永阻。 又承陛下令东方朔召西王母、夜置承露盘，即知陛下后悔之甚。 臣又闻事君尽忠，在朋立义，於君不忠，则人臣共罚； 不义於朋，则交友共弃。 臣於紫阳宫少微院西灶，躬受还丹妙道讫，依方潜录。 伏惟陛下，须纳忠臣谏，必效此方，莫比昔年，却从俗佞。 其药令左拾遗陈方景捣合，右丞周真宜候火，臣男志诚启垆并醮等，必锻炼精微。 愿懃诚志，紫琼暂逢，长为金骨。 陛下莫重含元大内，为上极精华。 北阙西堂，殊非至广。 太常九部，不足为声。 粉黛诸房，全为丑质。 矧此蓬莱妙绝殊境，得号仙山。 日殿月宫，云房金阁。 堂排金碧，楼焕珊瑚，鹊绕灵芝，鸾飞琼树。 天男玉女，沸鼎弦歌。 异鸟名禽，朝来不歇。 水精帘外，飒飒玄风。 碧玉户中，泠泠细雨。 琼浆一饮，少许千年； 大药暂餐，应期万载。 等闲见桑田为海水，见海水作桑田。 或即上朝天老，或自适云关，时下入瀛洲，散寻异宝。 寰中黄屋，不足为尊，补衮之流，未足为贵。 陛下何不生亲异境，而苦恋凡问。 目看冠葬石堂，身埋后土，使子孙空拜，沥酒寒陵，朝暮之间，即当见矣。 纵百年天子，不及一日仙人。 伏惟圣智审裁，莫自求其毙矣。 谨差南阳执药童，奉表以闻。 蓬莱山南阳紫微右长丞黄玄锺顿首谨言。 佥举臣此圣道，世不异求，惟在清斋，存心念静，设垆安灶，不得抵作方神，举措发机，须合天道。 其石药等，并须上好草药，勿令错误。 其药皆是州土进上，唯三般，出臣此山，以人间六味替用，并列如后。 石药黄牙歌一首，是造黄牙五言，草药形状名，采时节应用生死，一百七十二味草药歌，都合计一百六十八首。 造黄牙第－ 歌曰： 铺壬为迭迭，铅黄粉次重重。 牛酉白黄三色，依东尾咸浆味共通。 一安丙丁上，齐入赤炎中。 右依歌，并须重重，以壬尽为度，应夏至之节，以冰石研之佳，依东尾，忌甲戊庚除定等日。 露容草第二 俗为地录，书云石录。 茎花赤，性毒，恶理求体脉，生岩石，出河南，生甲乙，死戊己，甲寅，叶圆。 春分后二十日采，上治恶疮，应春分节。 歌日： 此药人问有，河南出最珍。 拈来和汞点，一夜应天真。 霜容草第三 俗为天涯，书为白微，性与上同。 出刻南道，生甲壬，死戊癸，引蔓三花，应夏至节，立春后采之。 歌日： 远树攀崖上，三花叶对峰。 拈来埋乙地，依东尾法还入癸壬中。 双夫草第四 俗名芙蔓，书为紫琼。 性与上同，治劳，出安南府。
